pageData.titleName2: Enthalpy of Formation Using Hess’s Law

pageData.text: In this investigation, the student will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy</button> of formation of magnesium oxide using <button class='glossary-text'>Hess’s law</button>. This requires the student to first calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> constant. The student will then perform two separate reactions, determining the heat generated in each reaction to calculate the enthalpy of formation of magnesium oxide.

pageData.text: In a refrigerator, Freon (CF<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>F) vapor is compressed causing the <button class='glossary-text'>pressure</button> to rise. This pressure pushes the vapor, which is hot, into the coils on the outside of the refrigerator. When the heated coils meet the cooler room temperature air in the room, it causes the vapor to become a liquid that remains at high pressure. The pressure keeps the now liquid Freon moving to coils within the refrigerator. The vapor interacts with the environment within the refrigerator by absorbing heat and dropping the temperature of the air. As the liquid absorbs this heat, it expands and vaporizes back into its original gas form. The vapor flows back into the compressor to begin the cycle again. Scientists use <button class='glossary-text'>Hess’s law</button> to calculate the heat of vaporization to determine how much heat would be required to turn liquid Freon into a gas, which is a critical step in the cooling process. This <button class='glossary-text'>endothermic reaction</button> allows us to enjoy long-term food storage and cold beverages.

pageData.text: Chemical thermodynamics is the study of energy changes that accompany change of physical state and chemical transformations. These changes occur through the generation or absorption of a <button class='glossary-text'>quantifiable amount of heat (q)</button>. If heat is generated during the chemical reaction or physical change, it is an <button class='glossary-text'>exothermic reaction</button>. If the heat is absorbed or needs to be added to the chemical reaction or physical change, then it is called an <button class='glossary-text'>endothermic reaction</button>.

Scientists use the term <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy (H)</button> to measure the total energy of a system (in <button class='glossary-text'>joules</button>). Enthalpy also accounts for any change in <button class='glossary-text'>volume</button> during a reaction, which is important when dealing with gas reactions. The equation for the enthalpy change of a reaction is:
=+P

Where ΔH is the change in enthalpy, Δq is the heat change (generation or absorption), P is , and ΔV is the change in volume. In most , pressure and volume are constant. Therefore, the equation becomes:
ΔH=Δq

Enthalpy is dependent on the amount of substance present. The enthalpy change for a reaction is generally written as a molar quantity. To calculate the molar enthalpy of a reaction (ΔHrxn), divide the reaction heat, (Δqrxn) by the number of moles of reactant or product.
ΔHrxn=Δqrxn/mol

Every chemical reaction either absorbs or emits heat when chemical bonds are formed or broken. Each chemical compound has a heat change associated with its formation. This heat change is <button class='glossary-text'>the standard enthalpy of formation</button> (ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>f</sub>°), and is the heat associated with the formation of one mole of a compound at one atmosphere of pressure at 25 °C.

In this investigation, <button class='glossary-text'>the standard enthalpy of formation</button> (ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>f</sub>°) will be determined for magnesium oxide (MgO). The overall equation for the formation of MgO is as follows:
Mg(s) + ½ O2(g) → MgO(s)
By definition the <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy</button> of reaction is the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the products minus the sum of the enthalpies of formation of the reactants.
ΔHrxn = Σ ΔHf (Products) – Σ ΔHf (Reactants)

Pure elements, such as magnesium and oxygen, are assigned a ΔH<sub class ='bodySubscript'>f</sub> of 0. The reactants in the formation of magnesium oxide are pure elements, meaning that the enthalpy of reaction will be equal to the enthalpy of formation for magnesium oxide. However, the reaction of solid magnesium with oxygen gas is not possible in normal lab conditions and would not be safe in a home environment. An alternative method for determining the ΔH<sub class ='bodySubscript'>f</sub>° for magnesium oxide is thus required. Fortunately, <button class='glossary-text'>Hess’s law</button> states that a reaction can be performed in steps, and the sum of the ΔH<sub class ='bodySubscript'>rxn</sub>° for each of those steps is equal to the ΔH<sub class ='bodySubscript'>f</sub>° for the compound in question (in this case, magnesium oxide). The synthesis of magnesium oxide is performed in the following three steps:

pageData.desc:
Equation 1          Mg(s) + 2 H+(aq) → Mg2+(aq) + H2 (g)    ΔH1
Equation 2          Mg2+(aq) + H2O(l) → MgO(s) + 2 H+(aq) ΔH2
Equation 3          H2(g) + ½ O2(g) → H2O(l)                         ΔH3
Overall Equation Mg(s) + ½ O2(g) → MgO(s)                       ΔHf = ΔH1 + ΔH2 + ΔH3
pageData.altText:
Equation 1          Mg(s) + 2 H+(aq) → Mg2+(aq) + H2 (g)    ΔH1
Equation 2          Mg2+(aq) + H2O(l) → MgO(s) + 2 H+(aq) ΔH2
Equation 3          H2(g) + ½ O2(g) → H2O(l)                         ΔH3
Overall Equation Mg(s) + ½ O2(g) → MgO(s)                       ΔHf = ΔH1 + ΔH2 + ΔH3

pageData.text: By adding equations 1, 2, and 3, and crossing out molecules found on both sides of the equation, the overall equation is obtained. Summation of their enthalpies gives the enthalpy of formation for MgO.

pageData.text: This investigation will be conducted using <button class='glossary-text'>calorimetry</button>. Calorimetry is the method by which heat energy is measured. The magnitude and the direction of heat transfer can be determined using a <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>, an insulated apparatus designed to create a closed system by preventing heat from flowing in or out. In this lab, the calorimeter is composed of two test tubes that are nested together with paper towels sandwiched between them. The paper towel between the two test tubes and the air surrounding the test tubes will insulate the system.

No calorimeter is a perfectly insulated system, and a fraction of the energy is absorbed by the calorimeter. The <button class='glossary-text'>joules</button> of energy absorbed per 1 °C temperature change represent the <button class='glossary-text'>heat capacity</button> (C) of the calorimeter. In Activity 1, the heat capacity of the calorimeter will be determined by analyzing the temperature change of cold water in the calorimeter when hot water is added. The difference between the heat lost by the hot water and the heat gained by the cold water will be due to the heat absorbed by the calorimeter (i.e., the heat capacity of the calorimeter).

pageData.text: A calibration curve is used to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>heat capacity</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. The calibration curve is a plot of the temperature (in °C) of the water in the calorimeter as a function of time. Plotting the temperature as a function of time will determine the cooling rate of the mixture. The initial mixing temperature is accurately calculated by fitting the data with a linear trend line using Excel<sup class ='bodySupscript'>™</sup>. Figure 1 shows a calibration curve generated from adding 50 g of water measuring 96 °C to 50 g of water measuring 24 °C. The initial temperature of the mixture should have been 60 °C [(96 + 24)/2 = 60]. The y-intercept from the linear trend curve is 57.4 °C and represents T<sub class ='bodySubscript'>final</sub>.
ΔT<sub class ='bodySubscript'>(hot water)</sub> = 57.4 °C – 96 °C = -38.6 °C
ΔT<sub class ='bodySubscript'>(cold water)</sub> = 57.4 °C – 24 °C = 33.4 °C

<button class='glossary-text'>Δq</button> is calculated by multiplying the heat capacity (C) of the substance by the change in temperature and the mass of the substance. The energy lost by this reaction (Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(hot water)</sub> + Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(cold water)</sub>) will be gained by the calorimeter (Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(cal)</sub>). Each calorimeter has a unique heat capacity based on the material of the calorimeter and the mass of solution within the calorimeter. In this investigation, the same <button class='glossary-text'>volume</button> of liquid will be used for each activity. Since the mass is constant for each activity, the mass of the calorimeter is not relevant to calculating Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(cal)</sub>.
Δq = C x ΔT x m
Δq(cal) = C(cal) x ΔT
Cwater = 4.18 J/g °C
Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(hot water)</sub> = 4.18 J/g °C x -38.6 °C x 50 g = -8067 J
Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>(cold water)</sub> = 4.18 J/g °C x 33.4 °C x 50 g = 6981 J
Energy lost to calorimeter = -1086 J
Δq(cal) = 1086 J = C(cal) x 33.4 °C
C<sub class='bodySubscript'>cal</sub> = 32.5 J/°C
For each reaction, Δqrxn is calculated as the sum of the heat absorbed by the solution and the heat absorbed by the calorimeter.
Δqrxn = -[Δqsoln + Δq(cal)]
In this investigation, it will be assumed that the heat capacity of the solution is the same as that of water (4.18 J/g-K).

In Activity 2, students will react magnesium metal with hydrochloric acid, as described in Equation 1. Students will measure the temperature change and calculate the heat generated during this reaction. In Activity 3, students will react magnesium oxide with hydrochloric acid. This reaction is the reverse of Equation 2, so the ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> will have the opposite sign when calculations are performed.

The reaction described in Equation 3 will not be performed because the heat of reaction of hydrogen and oxygen gases cannot be measured using a simple <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> such as the one that will be used in this activity. Instead, students will use the accepted value for the <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy</button> change of this reaction (–285.8 kJ/mol) when calculating ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>f</sub>.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 in this investigation. Before starting any of the activities, construct a test tube calorimeter. In Activity 1, you will add cold water to the calorimeter and measure its initial temperature. Then, you will heat some hot water, determine its initial temperature, and add it to the calorimeter. Afterward, you will record the temperature of the calorimeter water at regular intervals. This process is repeated for a total of three trials. Next, you will calculate the heat capacity of the calorimeter for each trial and the average heat capacity.

pages.title: Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter (14 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter (14 steps)

pageData.text: Measure 2.0 mL of water with a graduated cylinder and pour into the inner test tube of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. This is the cold water.
Remember that 1 mL of water = 1 g of water.
Place the calorimeter in the test tube rack for stability.
Stir the water with the thermometer until temperature is constant, and record it as the initial temperature of the cold water (Tc) in Data Table 1.
Fill the Styrofoam<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> cup 1/4 full with the hottest tap water possible.
Measure the temperature of the hot water. If the temperature is less than 75 °C, heat in a microwave with short bursts until the temperature reaches 75 °C.
Measure 2.0 mL of the hot water with a graduated cylinder.

Place a thermometer in the cylinder and gently stir until you obtain a constant temperature reading. The temperature should be 75–80 °C. Record this as the initial temperature of the hot water (Th) in Data Table 1.
Prepare the stopwatch or timer.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Quickly pour the 2.0 mL of hot water into the calorimeter containing the cold water and start a timer.
Gently stir the mixed water with the thermometer and record the temperature at 1-minute intervals for 10 minutes in Data Table 1.
Discard the water, dry the inner test tube with a paper towel, and place it back in the calorimeter.
Repeat this activity two additional times for a total of three trials.
Calculate the , as described on , of the calorimeter for each of the three trials and record the value in Data Table 1.
Calculate the average heat capacity of the calorimeter and record the value in Data Table 1.
In Activity 2, you will react magnesium metal with hydrochloric acid, as described in Equation 1. You will measure the temperature change and calculate the heat generated during this reaction.

pages.title: Determination of ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>rxn</sub> Mg and HCl (24 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Determination of ΔHrxn Mg and HCl (19 steps)

pageData.text: Place the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> in the test tube rack for stability.
Measure 4 mL of 1 M HCl with a graduated cylinder and pour it into the calorimeter.
Stir the HCl with a thermometer until the temperature is constant.
Record the initial temperature of the HCl in Data Table 2.
Place a weigh boat on the scale and tare (zero) the balance. Collect approximately 0.06 g of the magnesium metal strip and record the mass in Data Table 2.
Calculate the moles of magnesium (24.305 grams per mole) in the sample and record in Data Table 2.
Prepare the stopwatch or timer.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Place the magnesium strip into the calorimeter with the HCl and immediately start the timer.
Record the temperature at 1-minute intervals for a total of 10 minutes in Data Table 2.
Periodically stir the test tube with the thermometer as the reaction occurs, taking care not to spill any of the solution.
After 10 minutes, empty the contents into the sink with running water and rinse and dry the calorimeter.
Repeat this activity two additional times for a total of three trials.
For each trial, create a graph with temperature on the Y-axis and time on the X-axis.
Using a graphing software, calculate the linear regression for each graph utilizing only the temperatures from the portion of the graph where temperature is decreasing.
Record the equation of each linear regression line obtained with the graphing software in step 14 in Data Table 2.
The y-intercept of each line represents the final temperature for each corresponding trial. Record the final temperature in Data Table 2.
Calculate the temperature change (ΔT) for each trial and record in Data Table 2.
Calculate change in reaction heat (Δq<sub class='bodySubscript'>rxn</sub>) for each trial using the calorimeter constant calculated in Activity 1.
Calculate the average change in <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy</button>(ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript bodyFontBold'>1</sub>).

In Activity 3, you will react magnesium oxide with hydrochloric acid. This reaction is the reverse of Equation 2, so the ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> will have the opposite sign when calculations are performed. You will then use the data from all three activities to calculate the ΔH<sub class='bodySubscript'>f</sub> for magnesium oxide.

data.title: Calorimeter
data.content: An insulated apparatus designed to create a closed system by preventing heat from flowing in or out

data.title: Calorimetry
data.content: The method by which heat energy is measured

data.title: Endothermic Reaction
data.content: If the heat is absorbed or needs to be added to the chemical reaction or physical change

data.title: Enthalpy (H)
data.content: To measure the total energy of a system (in joules), also accounts for any change in volume during a reaction, ΔH=Δq+PΔV

data.title: Exothermic Reaction
data.content: If heat is generated during the chemical reaction or physical change

data.title: Heat capacity
data.content: The joules of energy absorbed per 1 °C temperature change

data.title: Hess’s law
data.content: States that a reaction can be performed in steps, and the sum of the ΔH<sub className='bodySubscript'>rxn</sub>° for each of those steps is equal to the ΔH<sub className='bodySubscript'>f</sub>°  for the compound in question (in this case, magnesium oxide).

data.title: Joules
data.content: International System of Units (SI unit) of work or energy

data.title: Pressure (P)
data.content: The force a gas exerts on its surroundings

data.title: Quantifiable amount of heat (q)
data.content: The amount of energy that is transferred

data.title: The standard enthalpy of formation
data.content: Each chemical compound has a heat change associated with its formation, the heat associated with the formation of one mole of a compound at one atmosphere of pressure at 25 °C.

data.title: Volume (V)
data.content: The three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or mL

data.title: ΔH
data.content: Delta H, the change in enthalpy

data.title: Δq
data.content: Delta q, the heat change (generation or absorption)

data.title: ΔV
data.content: Delta V, the change in volume
